channel.title: NYT > U.S. > Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Muslims Move to Assert Political Power in New York City
item.description: Zohran Mamdani’s ascension to mayor has given Muslim organizers and faith leaders the impetus to insert themselves into more formal political alliances and networks.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Thursday, a group consisting mostly of Muslim organizers and faith leaders in the Bronx voted to join the Metro Industrial Areas Foundation, one of the nation’s oldest nonpartisan organizing networks.

item.title: TrumpRx, the President’s Online Drugstore, Opens for Business
item.description: TrumpRx is aimed at helping patients use their own money to buy medicines. But researchers who study drug pricing warned that many patients could pay too much if they use the site.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:description: The TrumpRx website is meant to be an entry point for consumers to search for their medicines and then direct them to manufacturers’ websites to buy the drugs directly.

item.title: Virginia Democrats Propose New Congressional Maps Ahead of Midterms
item.description: As they appeal a ruling blocking their redistricting efforts, the state’s Democrats proposed redrawing districts in a way that would strongly favor them.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Mike Kropf/Richmond Times-Dispatch via Associated Press
item.media:description: Virginia’s proposed congressional map is one of the most significant moves by Democrats in the national redistricting arms race that has engulfed about a dozen states over the past year.

item.title: Lawmakers Say They Will Not Cooperate With Inquiry Into Illegal Orders Video
item.description: The Justice Department investigation was an escalation in the administration’s response to a video that President Trump said was “punishable by death.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro

item.title: Pentagon Official Rejects Plea Deal in U.S.S. Cole Bombing Case
item.description: The decision clears the way for the first death-penalty trial at Guantánamo Bay to start this summer, more than 25 years after the attack.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S.S. Cole at a Yemeni harbor in October 2000, more than two weeks after an attack by Al Qaeda suicide bombers killed 17 sailors and wounded dozens of others.

item.title: Senators Clash Over Immigration Enforcement, Risking a D.H.S. Shutdown
item.description: With eight days until a deadline to keep the Department of Homeland Security running, bipartisan talks on reining in federal immigration agents’ tactics appeared to sputter before they had even gotten underway.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senators left Washington for the weekend without opening serious talks on a measure needed to keep the Department of Homeland Security running past a Feb. 13 midnight deadline.

item.title: Kennedy Makes Unfounded Claim That Keto Diet Can ‘Cure’ Schizophrenia
item.description: The claim vastly overstates preliminary research into whether the high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet might help people with the disorder, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in Nashville on Wednesday. Mr. Kennedy has a history of promoting ideas with little to no scientific evidence to back them up.

item.title: Myra MacPherson, 91, Dies; Wrote Wrenchingly About Vietnam Vets, Dies
item.description: A political reporter at The Washington Post, she wrote the book “Long Time Passing,” about the Vietnam War’s social, political and psychological aftereffects.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Myra MacPherson in 1967 when she worked at The New York Times. She left the next year to join The Washington Post, where she went on to cover five presidential elections.

item.title: Facing a Democratic Blitz, Susan Collins Scores a Super Bowl Ad in Maine
item.description: The ad is part of a multimillion dollar effort by a Republican-aligned group to help Ms. Collins, who is seen as one of the party’s most vulnerable incumbents.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan M. Collins is facing what is expected to be a fierce Democratic challenge in November.

item.title: White House Offers Shifting Story on Gabbard’s Presence at Georgia Raid
item.description: President Trump said Thursday that Attorney General Pam Bondi had directed Tulsi Gabbard to be present for an operation at an election center. It was the administration’s fourth explanation for her presence.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard at the Fulton County elections office in Atlanta last week.

item.title: TrumpRx Is Set to Go Live on Thursday
item.description: The government website is meant to connect Americans with drug companies to buy prescriptions directly with their own money. It is not clear how many patients will save money.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: President Trump announced an effort to lower drug prices last year.

item.title: Secretary Rubio Gives Up Role as Acting U.S. Archivist
item.description: Mr. Rubio had been the acting head of the National Archives since early 2025, after President Trump fired its previous chief. His tenure was limited to 300 days by law.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio has been assigned a variety of acting roles by President Trump.

item.title: Trump Strips Job Protections From Thousands of Federal Workers
item.description: The policy change makes it easier for the president to discipline or remove up to 50,000 employees, another push in the administration’s campaign to reshape the federal work force.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters in Washington last year. More than 352,000 employees left the federal government in 2025, according to the most recent data.

item.title: Congress Nixes Visas for Afghan Partners, Closing Off a Key Path
item.description: President Trump froze a program to allow Afghans who had worked with American troops to come to the United States. Now Congress has quietly scrapped the visas, leaving little hope of reviving them.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Zia Ghafoori in 2019 with a commemorative Purple Heart he received while working with U.S. forces in Afghanistan.

item.title: The G.O.P. Senator Who Can’t Stop Thinking About the Boy ICE Detained
item.description: Katie Britt is uniquely positioned to reason with the Trump administration — when she chooses to speak up.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kitchener
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Katie Britt of Alabama has emerged as a Republican uniquely positioned to reason with the Trump administration.

item.title: What Restrictions Are Democrats Demanding for Immigration Agents?
item.description: Democrats say they will not support a spending bill to keep the Homeland Security Department running without new restrictions on federal agents.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: ICE agents in St. Paul, Minn., last month. Among Democrats’ demands are that federal agents wear body cameras and take off the masks they have worn during raids.

item.title: F.D.A. Relaxes Rules on ‘Naturally Derived’ Dyes
item.description: Food makers will now be able to claim that their products have “no artificial colors,” so long as they use dyes that are not petroleum-based.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: “We’re asking people now, ‘Eat real food,’” Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said at the Tennessee State Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: Surge in Immigration Cases in Minnesota Pushes Prosecutors and Judges to Brink
item.description: Remarks by a prosecutor opened a revealing window onto how the courts in the state are buckling under the weight of a deluge of cases arising from the Trump administration’s campaign.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Mattathias Schwartz and Zach Montague
item.media:description: Hundreds of immigrants have been arrested in Minnesota in recent weeks.

item.title: How Trump Brought the Fight Over American History to Philadelphia
item.description: The administration took a crowbar to a site that focused on George Washington and slavery. But can the contradictions of the Founding Era be erased?
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The protest signs have mixed grief, anger and local Philadelphia pride. “Slavery is Real, Go Birds!” one read.

item.title: Save the ‘Sistine Chapel of the New Deal’ in the Cohen Federal Building
item.description: The rare murals in the Cohen Federal Building celebrate vital American values of dignity and community. Now they could meet the same fate as the White House’s East Wing.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter

item.title: To Win Back the House, Democrats Take the Fight to Deep-Red Areas
item.description: Democrats are tapping candidates with unusual résumés — a Tejano recording star, a smokejumper and a fourth-generation farmer — to compete in areas long seen as inhospitable.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Gabriel V. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democratic strategists believe that Bobby Pulido could be the kind of political unicorn who can put a seat that President Trump won by a whopping 18 percentage points in play this fall by appealing to working-class Latino voters.

item.title: Nuclear Arms Control Era Comes to End Amid Global Rush for New Weapons
item.description: Beijing, Moscow and shaken American allies are seeking new warheads as President Trump ends more than a half century of nuclear arms control with Russia.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Alaska last year.
